thread.title: ‘Anchor babies’? Rubio says they’re ‘human beings’
thread.title_full: ‘Anchor babies’? Rubio says they’re ‘human beings’ - MarketWatch

author: Robert Schroeder
title: ‘Anchor babies’? Rubio says they’re ‘human beings’
text:
No “anchor babies” for Marco Rubio.
Rubio, the Florida Republican senator running for president, declined to use the controversial term when interviewed Thursday by CNBC’s John Harwood . Rubio’s term for children born in the U.S. to parents who didn’t enter legally? “Human beings.” Jeb Bush, Donald Trump and others have used the term anchor babies, which some find offensive. “Well, these are 13 million — those are human beings,” Rubio said. “And ultimately, they are people. They are not just statistics. They are human beings with stories.”
Trump on no-new-taxes pledge: Donald Trump is “thinking” about signing a no-new-taxes pledge offered to candidates by activist Grover Norquist, he told Time magazine in an extensive interview. But, said the Republican presidential frontrunner, he may “have a problem because I may want to switch taxes around.” Trump said he wants to save the middle class and singled out “hedge fund guys” who make a lot of money “that aren’t paying anything.” He said he doesn’t know how the pledge would relate to them.
Read: Brett Arends says Trump’s tax plan would save his family billions
Pentagon probing Ashley Madison use: Politico reports the Pentagon is investigating the release of the more than 13,000 email addresses with military domain names that may have been used to log into the Ashley Madison web site . On Thursday, Defense Secretary Ash Carter was asked about the release of the emails by hackers, and said: “Of course it’s an issue, because conduct is very important, and we expect good conduct on the part of our people.” The site is dedicated to people seeking to cheat on their spouses.
What could haunt a Biden bid: Legislation known as the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act could haunt a bid for the White House by Vice President Joe Biden if he chooses to run , writes the New York Times. The 1994 legislation is again the subject of fierce debate, with activists and lawmakers seeking to undo the era of mass incarceration they say the bill helped to create. Biden, a former chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, helped to pass the act, which touches on nearly every aspect of U.S. law enforcement.
George’s pitch for Jeb: Jeb Bush has a new partner in fundraising: his brother George . The Hill writes former President George W. Bush penned a fundraising letter sent out Thursday on behalf of his brother, who’s seeking the Republican presidential nomination. George W. Bush noted in the email sent to Jeb Bush’s campaign list he “rarely” pens such letters. But Quote: : “My brother will be a tremendous president.” And he added: “He’s got a tough road ahead — take it from someone who’s been there.”
